briefdescription.para: More accurate nearest node queries.

detaileddescription.para: When on, looks for the closest point on every triangle instead of if point is inside the node triangle in XZ space. This is slower, but a lot better if your mesh contains overlaps (e.g bridges over other areas of the mesh). Note that for maximum effect the Full Get Nearest Node Search setting should be toggled in A* Inspector Settings.

briefdescription.para: Voxel sample size (y)
Voxel sample size (x,z)
Max distance from simplified edge to real edge.
Center of the bounding box.

detaileddescription.para: Scanning will only be done inside the bounding box

briefdescription.para: Size of the bounding box.
Include the Terrain in the scene.
Masks which objects to include.
Longer edges will be subdivided.

detaileddescription.para: Reducing this value can improve path quality since similarly sized polygons yield better paths than really large and really small next to each other

briefdescription.para: Max slope in degrees the character can traverse.
Show an outline of the polygons in the Unity Editor.
Controls how large the sample size for the terrain is.

detaileddescription.para: A higher value is faster but less accurate

briefdescription.para: Use a C++ version of Recast.

detaileddescription.para:
The C++ version is faster and has more features, though right now the features are quite similar because I haven't added support for them yet. The C++ version can only be used in the editor or in standalones and it requires a special file to be placed inside the executable for standalones. When deploying for mac, the Recast file (which can be found in the AstarPathfindingProject folder) should be copied to a new folder myApplication.app/Contents/Recast/
When deploying for windows, the Recast file should be copied to the data folder/Recast/
You can however save a cache of the graph scanned in the editor and use that in a webplayer but you cannot rescann any graphs in the webplayer I have no information on whether or not it would work using iPhone or Android, so I would refrain form trying to use it there (though you can still cache graphs as you can with the webplayer)

briefdescription.para: Height the character can climb.
Character height.
Bounding Box Tree.

detaileddescription.para:
Enables really fast lookups of nodes. A* Pro Feature:

memberdef.argsstring: (GraphNode n1, GraphNode n2, List< Vector3 > left, List< Vector3 > right)
memberdef.name: AddPortal

briefdescription.para: Add the portal between node n1 and n2 to the funnel corridor.

detaileddescription.para: The left and right edges does not necesarily need to be the left and right edges (right can be left), they will be swapped if that is detected. But that works only as long as the edges do not switch between left and right in the middle of the path.

memberdef.argsstring: (List< GraphNode > path, int startIndex, int endIndex, List< Vector3 > left, List< Vector3 > right)
memberdef.name: BuildFunnelCorridor

briefdescription.para: Creates a number of nodes with the correct type for the graph.

detaileddescription.para: This should not set the #nodes array, only return the nodes. Called by graph generators and when deserializing a graph with nodes. Override this function if you do not use the default Pathfinding.Node class.

briefdescription.para: Deserializes graph type specific node data.
Returns the nearest node to a position using the specified NNConstraint.

parameterdescription.para: The position to try to find a close node to
Can be passed to enable some graph generators to find the nearest node faster.
Can for example tell the function to try to return a walkable node. If you do not get a good node back, consider calling GetNearestForce.

briefdescription.para: Returns the nearest node to a position using the specified constraint.

simplesect.para: A NNInfo. This function will only return an empty NNInfo if there is no nodes which comply with the specified constraint.

memberdef.argsstring: (Vector3 origin, Vector3 end, GraphNode hint, out GraphHitInfo hit)
memberdef.name: Linecast

briefdescription.para: Scans the graph, called from AstarPath.Scan Override this function to implement custom scanning logic
Serializes graph type specific node data.

detaileddescription.para: This function can be overriden to serialize extra node information (or graph information for that matter) which cannot be serialized using the standard serialization. Serialize the data in any way you want and return a byte array. When loading, the exact same byte array will be passed to the DeserializeExtraInfo function. These functions will only be called if node serialization is enabled. If null is returned from this function, the DeserializeExtraInfo function will not be called on load.

briefdescription.para: Updates an area using the specified GraphUpdateObject.

detaileddescription.para:
Notes to implementators. This function should (in order):
Call o.WillUpdateNode on the GUO for every node it will update, it is important that this is called BEFORE any changes are made to the nodes.
Update walkabilty using special settings such as the usePhysics flag used with the GridGraph.
Call Apply on the GUO for every node which should be updated with the GUO.
Update eventual connectivity info if appropriate (GridGraphs updates connectivity, but most other graphs don't since then the connectivity cannot be recovered later).

briefdescription.para: Automatically generates navmesh graphs based on world geometry.

detaileddescription.para:
The recast graph is based on Recast (http://code.google.com/p/recastnavigation/). I have translated a good portion of it to C# to run it natively in Unity. The Recast process is described as follows:
The voxel mold is build from the input triangle mesh by rasterizing the triangles into a multi-layer heightfield. Some simple filters are then applied to the mold to prune out locations where the character would not be able to move.
The walkable areas described by the mold are divided into simple overlayed 2D regions. The resulting regions have only one non-overlapping contour, which simplifies the final step of the process tremendously.
The navigation polygons are peeled off from the regions by first tracing the boundaries and then simplifying them. The resulting polygons are finally converted to convex polygons which makes them perfect for pathfinding and spatial reasoning about the level.

It works exactly like that in the C# version as well, except that everything is triangulated to triangles instead of n-gons. The recast generation process completely ignores colliders since it only works on an existing "polygon soup". This is usually a good thing though, because world geometry is usually more detailed than the colliders.

sect1.title: Exporting for manual editing
sect1.para: In the editor there is a button for exporting the generated graph to a .obj file. Usually the generation process is good enough for the game directly, but in some cases you might want to edit some minor details. So you can export the graph to a .obj file, open it in your favourite 3D application, edit it, and export it to a mesh which Unity can import. Then you assign that new mesh to the "Replacement Mesh" field right below the export button. That mesh will then be used to calculate the graph.

Since many 3D modelling programs use different axis systems (unity uses X=right, Y=up, Z=forward), it can be a bit tricky to get the rotation and scaling right. For blender for example, what you have to do is to first import the mesh using the .obj importer. Don't change anything related to axes in the settings. Then select the mesh, open the transform tab (usually the thin toolbar to the right of the 3D view) and set Scale -> Z to -1. If you transform it using the S (scale) hotkey, it seems to set both Z and Y to -1 of some reason. Then make the edits you need and export it as an .obj file to somewhere in the Unity project. But this time, edit the setting named "Forward" to "Z forward" (not -Z as it is per default).

listitem.para: This is an A* Pathfinding Project Pro feature only. This function/class/variable might not exist in the Free version of the A* Pathfinding Project or the functionality might be limited The Pro version can be bought here
